topic: What role should artificial intelligence play in society, and how should its risks be governed?

statements.statement: Artificial intelligence should be used to make everyday life more efficient, create good-paying jobs, and help businesses like mine serve customers better, not to replace the value of human judgment and hard work. We need clear, common-sense regulations that hold companies accountable for how AI is used, protect privacy and free speech, and prevent government or big tech from using it to track or control people.

statements.statement: Artificial intelligence should be used mainly to make life more efficient and secure—improving healthcare, protecting our borders, and helping police and emergency services do their jobs better. But it must always stay under strict human control, with clear laws, strong oversight, and real consequences when companies or governments misuse it. We should protect privacy, jobs, and traditional values first, instead of letting big tech and unaccountable experts decide everything.

statements.statement: As a nurse, I see every day how AI could help us catch problems earlier, reduce errors, and give patients more personalized care—but it should support human judgment, not replace it. We need strong, enforceable regulations that prioritize patient safety, data privacy, and transparency about how AI systems make decisions, with input from frontline workers and communities, not just tech companies. AI tools should be tested like medical devices, held accountable when they cause harm, and designed to reduce inequities in healthcare and education, not deepen them.

statements.statement: Artificial intelligence should be used to make work safer, more efficient, and fairer—especially for people on the warehouse floor and in other blue-collar jobs, not just for executives and tech companies. But we need strong, enforceable rules so AI can’t be used to exploit workers, discriminate against people of color, or invade our privacy, and those rules should come from democratic processes, not just corporate promises. As a Catholic and a progressive, I think AI has to be guided by respect for human dignity and the common good, with real accountability when it causes harm.

statements.statement: AI should be used to expand access—to education, healthcare, and creative opportunities—especially for people who are usually left out, not just to make rich companies richer. But because it can be biased, invasive, and easily abused by those in power, we need strong, democratic oversight: clear regulations, independent audits, transparency about how systems work, and real consequences when companies or governments misuse it. As someone who values diversity and lives in a very human, social world, I think AI should support human connection and dignity, never replace or devalue it.

statements.statement: As someone who works in tech and manages complex projects, I see artificial intelligence as a powerful tool that can make our work more efficient and free up time for what really matters—our families, our communities, and caring for one another. But it shouldn’t be a free-for-all: we need clear, enforceable rules that protect privacy, prevent discrimination, and ensure humans remain accountable for important decisions. I’d like to see industry, government, and community voices at the same table so that AI serves people broadly, not just the interests of a few large companies.

statements.statement: As someone who spent her life teaching and now volunteers in my local library, I see artificial intelligence as a powerful tool that should support education, healthcare, and environmental protection, especially for the young and the elderly. But like any powerful tool, it needs careful, transparent rules set by both experts and ordinary citizens, so that companies and governments can’t use it to invade privacy, spread misinformation, or replace human care and judgment. We should insist on strong oversight, clear accountability, and a focus on the common good, so AI strengthens our communities instead of weakening them.

statements.statement: At my age, I’ve seen medicine and technology transform lives, and I believe artificial intelligence can be a powerful tool to improve healthcare, reduce loneliness among older people, and make everyday services more accessible. But no machine should ever replace human judgment, compassion, or responsibility, especially in caring professions. We need strong, transparent regulations, public oversight, and protections against bias and abuse so AI serves everyone fairly, not just corporations or the wealthy. Above all, the people most affected—patients, workers, and ordinary citizens—must have a real voice in how these systems are designed and used.

statements.statement: I think artificial intelligence should mostly be used to help people with important stuff, like making medicine better, helping students learn in their own way, and solving big problems like pollution. But there should be strict rules so companies and governments can’t spy on people or control them with AI, and there should always be real humans checking what AI does. I also think we should teach kids in school how AI works and what its limits are, so people don’t just blindly trust it.
